user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_CallOnce:
```c
void UT_Stub_CallOnce(void (*Func)(void))
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *OnceEnt;
    UT_EntryKey_t        FuncKey;
    int32                i;

    if (Func == NULL)
    {
        return;
    }

    FuncKey = (UT_EntryKey_t)Func;
    OnceEnt = NULL;
    StubPtr = UT_StubTable;
    for (i = 0; i < UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS; ++i)
    {
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED && OnceEnt == NULL)
        {
            OnceEnt = StubPtr;
        }
        else if (StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALL_ONCE && StubPtr->FuncKey == FuncKey)
        {
            OnceEnt = StubPtr;
            break;
        }
        ++StubPtr;
    }

    if (OnceEnt == NULL)
    {
        /* should never happen -- UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS needs increase if it does */
        UtAssert_Abort("Cannot do CallOnce - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
    }
    else if (OnceEnt->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        OnceEnt->EntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALL_ONCE;
        OnceEnt->FuncKey   = FuncKey;

        Func();
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Stub_CallOnce:
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
#define UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS 200
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t UT_StubTable[UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS] = {{0}}
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are used in the provided code. Specifically:
- Function pointer parameter syntax (void (*Func)(void)), function calls, control structures (for, if/else), increments and array indexing are all standard C constructs.
- The static array initialization static UT_StubTableEntry_t UT_StubTable[UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS] = {{0}} uses standard aggregate initialization (double braces for array of structs is standard) and zero initialization; this is not a compiler extension.
- The typedefs shown (int32 from int32_t, UT_StubTableEntry_t struct, and UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS macro) are standard C uses of typedef/macros.
- The cast FuncKey = (UT_EntryKey_t)Func converts a function pointer to an integer-typed alias (UT_EntryKey_t). Although conversion between pointers and integer types is implementation-defined in C (and thus can vary by platform), it is not by itself a compiler language extension as defined by compiler extension documentation. Therefore it is not reported under MISRA C:2012 Rule 1.2 per the instruction to report only explicit compiler-documented extensions.

One potential area that could be a compiler-specific type is the underlying definition of cpuaddr (used in typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t). If cpuaddr is a compiler-provided nonstandard built-in type (rather than a project typedef to a standard integer type like uintptr_t/unsigned long), then the typedef line using cpuaddr would be a language extension and should be investigated. However, that definition is not present in the provided code or compiler documentation here, so it cannot be definitively flagged. If you can provide the definition of cpuaddr (or compiler documentation stating cpuaddr is an extension), I can re-evaluate and mark that fragment as suspicious.
